10/10 — A Roguelike Masterpiece 

The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is one of the most rewarding, addictive, and brilliantly designed roguelikes ever made. Every run feels completely unique thanks to its massive pool of items, enemies, and room variations. No matter how many hours you put in, the game always finds a new way to surprise you — a broken synergy you’ve never seen, a devil deal that changes your whole build, or a chaotic moment that turns disaster into triumph.

The gameplay is tight, responsive, and incredibly satisfying. Early runs feel scrappy and tense, but once you start stacking items and discovering powerful combos, the game transforms into a wild, unpredictable power fantasy. The amount of variety is incredible: dozens of characters, multiple final bosses, branching paths, secret floors, hidden challenges, and endless item interactions that keep you experimenting run after run.

But more than anything, Isaac has soul. Its dark humor, eerie atmosphere, and unsettling themes create a world that’s weirdly emotional and strangely compelling. The pixel art is beautifully detailed, the soundtrack is hauntingly memorable, and every element of the game leans into its twisted, surreal identity in a way few games dare to.

The replay value is practically infinite. You can play for 20 hours or 2,000 hours and still discover new combinations, secrets, and strategies. It’s a game that respects your time, rewards your skill, and constantly pushes you to grow, learn, and adapt.

Whether you’re chasing unlocks, aiming for high-difficulty runs, or just enjoying the chaos of unpredictable item synergies, Rebirth delivers an experience that is unmatched in the genre. It is challenging, creative, dark, brilliant — and endlessly replayable.

A must-play.One of the greatest roguelikes ever made.

Out of any rougelike I have ever played, Isaac stands out as one of a kind. There is no other game that gives the possibilities, and synergies that exist in Isaac. After playing for 30 hours I see many of the same items, but none of my runs ever feel the same. Isaac offers a huge amount of replayability, on top of that the game itself is just fun. Although I'm a little late on playing Isaac, I can say that in a time when rougelikes have become somewhat repetitive and uninspired. Isaac stands as a beacon in the genre as a timeless game. I wouldn't be suprised if this becomes one of my most played games. If you enjoy rougelikes and you haven't played Isaac, then play Isaac, because it will give you possibly the best rougelike experience you will ever get.

Isaac is one of those games that grabs you from the first run and refuses to let go. The blend of grotesque humor, unsettling atmosphere, and strangely charming art style creates a world that feels unlike anything else. What truly makes the game shine, though, is how every item you pick up can completely reshape your run, turning chaos into surprising synergies that feel both ridiculous and brilliant. The achievement system is woven deeply into the experience, constantly rewarding you with new items, characters, and secrets that keep expanding the game long after you think you have seen everything. No matter how many times I die, I always feel that pull to jump into just one more run, and somehow each one still manages to feel fresh. For me, this remains one of the most addictive, replayable, and cleverly designed roguelikes ever made.

As one of, if not THE, original roguelikes to popularize the genre, this game really delivers a type of fun that's difficult to normally get into. Bullet hell is usually off putting due to the pressure normally put on the player to avoid taking any kind of damage. Binding of Isaac is much more forgiving but can be at times just as brutal with a gameplay loop full of unlocks that delivers a very satisfying result. Absolutely worth a try just to know where a lot of this genre comes from, and as a relic of older flash game days.

Confident in claiming that this is genuinely one of the best roguelikes to have ever graced the genre. There is so much to this one, it is almost intimidating at this point. My review will be based off the full game with all DLCs, because you should honestly be playing with all of them for the best experience. Except maybe Repentance+, that one is up to your discretion as I normally don't play with it.

Gameplay is simple to start but incredibly satisfying to master as it becomes more complex. Learning how to approach enemies and situations, as well as manipulate your own luck to turn the tides in your favor is a skill unto itself. Don't get me wrong, there is plenty of randomness to the game and sometimes you will get absolutely shafted, but by-and-large it feels fair and wouldn't be as replayable without some bad runs here and there. 

Build variety here is incredibly diverse. With over 700 different items and a massive amount of synergies between them, it will actually be quite rare that you have runs that feel the same. Plus, with such a massive repertoire of potential build paths, you can make almost any run a winner if you practice the main gameplay. Honestly, variety really is the name of the game here, not just with items. Trinkets, health types, enemies, bosses, special encounters, endings, hell the sheer amount of just room layouts in this game is STAGGERING. The majority of the characters are unique and offer very interesting ways to engage with build choice. Challenges are super fun and give you even more new ways to play, although I do feel like there could be more by this point. Bosses are fantastic for the most part and ending ones in particular can be quite challenging.

Visuals in the game are phenomenal for the style, and in particular Repentance adds many new animations and crispness. Music is full of bangers and still slaps after over 500 hours. Of course, despite it not being the main focus of the game, the story is fantastic. I love the way that a lot of the bosses and items weave into the narrative. It is dark, witty, and at many moments quite sad and heart-wrenching. I still catch some feelings when ascending to Home.

Although it is not a reflection of the game itself, I would be remiss if I didn't mention the modding community. A fantastic community of people who have made so many amazing mods for the game, ranging from QoL and visual upgrades, to hilarious animations and audio changes, to content packs that add EVEN MORE variety to the game, to gameplay and character mods that completely change the fundamentals of the game itself. Obviously I think it's best to stay vanilla at first and experience the game as intended, but the mods are absolutely worth diving into once you have.

This is THE quintessential roguelike experience, the pioneer. If you haven't at least tried it yet, you are absolutely missing out. One of my top games of all time, 10/10.

If this game didn't spawn the "action-roguelike" genre, it certainly put it on the map.  Countless games have followed the blueprints laid out by Isaac, but none have felt as deep or complete.  There is just so much to achieve and unlock, and the loop is so fun to keep trying, that this game is meant to be enjoyed over years not hours.  It's got just enough difficulty and randomness that you come to realize there are no "unfair" runs.  You just should have made better decisions.  The cherry on top are the updates and balancing we still get after all these years.
This game will test you're patience. Many times will you rage. However when you finally understand and get a good run you will be the happiest person on earth

The Best Roguelike: Game Score 10/10

The sequel that fixed pretty much everything that original Isaac was missing. The best thing about Binding of Isaac (BOI) is that every run is save able and winnable, there is very rarely a run that can not be beat and made to work with good play or a room that forces you to take damage if played correctly. The amount of characters, items and side routes especially with the DLC this game got means that playability is so vast that I may never 100% this game. BOI is one of the most complete roguelike experiences you can get. The most nuanced synergy system of items I've ever seen in a rogue like, almost every item interacts with each other in a way or another. The DLC and updates it receives consistently makes you always come back to it.

The gameplay of BOI is definitely the main hook of the game, but the art style and music in Isaac is different and interesting. The art style is sometimes grim, sometimes colorful and sometimes just silly. This art direction helps categorize and make items and item classes (devil items, mom items or angel items) much more recognizable and fun. The music and sound effects are nothing I would maybe listen to outside of playing the game, but nonetheless these pieces and effects fit perfectly to the atmosphere of the game and make the experience so much better and fuller.
A game that literally never gets boring. With over 2300 hours in this game, I still find myself discovering items and having challenges. 10/10
The gameplay is nice, even tough it is repetitive but it has variation that make it feel non-repetitive. Would recommend to buy the DLC's tough, worth every penny.

I was going to wait until I 100%ed this game to review, as I often do, but I just cannot. This game has been one of my favorites for so long. It is what introduced me to one of my favorite genres of games, all that stuff. That is when I was bad at complex thought. This game is not good. This game seems to be almost entirely luck based, and unlike so many other games in the genre, there is no way to mitigate that fact. There is no way to increase the quantity or quality of items and quite literally nothing is reliable in this game. I can excuse that, to an extent, but what I cannot excuse is the genuine fucking torture that is the tainted characters. The tainted characters are fun a lot of the time, yes. They are also genuinely awful to deal with. Tainted lost is one of the worst gaming experiences I have ever had the displeasure of dealing with. I love risk vs reward characters, and this is a character that expands upon that from one of my favorite characters, base lost. Unlike base lost, however, this one is bullshit. You get one hit per run a lot of the time. Which yes, is the ultimate skill check, but also, in a game that is so built on the leniency of getting hit, considering the bullshit spawning mechanics, tainted lost is so dreadful to play with. There should not be a skill check character in a game that so heavily relies on luck for anything to get done. And on the topic of luck, one of the ONLY ways in which you can mitigate it is by minmaxing every single floor. Which is fine, I enjoy minmaxing because of something that is wrong with me. But of course, there are speedrun achievements, So that is just more luck. And that is compounded when you are playing the other most dreadful character, tainted cain. I like tainted cain in concept. He is just so unfun to play with. Any run with him will take about 3 times as long as a different characters, and you still need speedrun achievements while playing him, which either entails getting the singular crafting recipe that allows you to skip said time requirement, or just not have basically any items. Genuinely fucking dreadful. There are numerous other things I could mention, like a couple of the challenges, which McMillen has gone on record stating that one of them is straight up not fun. but one thing is the fucking price oh my god. If you want the "full" experience, you need to pay for so much dlc. The base game is fine, more enjoyable even, but attempting to move from console to pc or something like that costs so much money. Oh my god and the curses. The fucking curse. On hard mode, which is the main mode you will be using if you want to beat the game, you have a 1 in 3 chance to have a curse on each floor, and they are frankly just not fun. Curses affect information and movement, and only one is even remotely entertaining, the other are just a nuisance, especially curse of the blind. It isn't fun to have less information, all it does is take up more of your time in this timesink of a game. Finally, before i write another essay length review, I just do not like how many achievements there are. I love achievements, but there is an achievement for every single unlock. It feels cheap. I understand the reasoning, but having a game with 644 achievements skews my stats in a way that is simply not that fun. So even outside of the game it causes issues. But for the good, the atmosphere and music is great, as well as the fact that when you do get a good run, it is genuinely very fun (provided you don't get tapped by a random little guy as tainted lost and lose 3 hours of progress without any fault of your own). This is not a very unbiased review. Im just mad. I sure the game is slightly better than I have portrayed it, but none of my critiques have been even close to nitpicks (other than the amount of achievements). Overall, it is a fine game, fun even. Is it a good enough game to actually play? No.

This is definitely a great game, and if you enjoy the base version then the DLCs are absolutely worth it. With that said, if you like to 100% games, you could honestly do better than sinking your teeth into the bone and nail sandwich that is this game. This game will not respect your time, and 100% is frankly a ridiculous endeavor. So, let's perform a little science experiment on how long it could take you!

Let's assume that you, a new player, are absolutely godly at this game, and never die. In order to complete one of the harder achievements in the game, you must beat one of the final bosses in under 20 minutes, which is no small feat by any means. But you? YOU can beat any final boss within 20 minutes! And seeing as there are 11 main endings to reach you begin your trek. So, you do this, and for that character with no deaths and a consistent fast pace can complete every mark in just 3 Hours and 30 minutes! (I'm shaving off some time here to make it easier to read and also because you are a God Gamer)
Now for the 'compounding'. You have 16 other characters that you need to do the 11 endings with as well. Some of these characters have some fun gimmicks, but mostly are the same character, with a few notable exceptions. (The Forgotten and Lost my beloved)
So, 17 X 3 Hours and 30 Minutes would round up to 59 and a half hours, or 2 days and a half.
That isn't some small feat, mind you, if you were really gunning for 100% on other games you could probably complete them in around 10, maybe 20 hours, but you sunk your entire weekend nonstop and finally got through it all!
And then you press the E button, and find yourself face to face with the OTHER 17 characters, each with their own unique play styles wildly different from the last! So, take your time and double it, 5 whole days. Now, if I played a game for roughly 100 hours, I'd maybe start to get bored of it. But since you are gunning for aiming for 100%, you stick with it, managing to flawlessly beat the two tainted characters that can die in one hit if you're being silly. No deaths!
But did you really beat all of those in one sitting? Of course not, you're not a psycho! You did it all across a month so you can get your Daily Run in!
You know, the Daily Run?
The one you had to "attempt" *run into the nearest fire within the first minute* every day for 31 days? With no tracker of how many days you've completed? God I HOPE you did, because logging in just to do that specifically would be annoying! And your reward for such *Dedication*?
A pill that fires an explosive round that, unless you remember about that one pill out of other possible 48, will most likely hurt you if you are too close to a wall. God help you if you were about to fight the boss that teleports at random through the arena, moving faster than you can go at max speed without a shield as the character who dies in one hit without that said shield!
But you didn't, right? YOU beat them, first try, you legend! You managed to scrape by using only Bob's Brain, a pair of scissors, and the ability to spawn a single poop per room! You never reset the run, you just took what the game gave you! So what if you were missing a key for 3 straight floors and as soon as you open the treasure room are met with a fly that floats around your head to damage enemies? You can work with that!
But now you are prepared for the REAL fun: The Challenges, of course! All 45 of them, assuming 20 minutes, another 15 hours, no knock off your belt. 
Even the challenge which makes it so every item has an unknowable effect that could either make you God or summon 30 flies every time you pick up a coin was no issue.
And same with the one that doesn't let you heal, makes all items invisible, and whose only legitimate accepted strategy in the entire community is to just reset until you have 2 specific items! And makes every enemy stronger, while expecting you to go down one of the longer routes of the game. Even the game developer said "I never said it was fun" when asked about the challenge REQUIRED for 100%.
But the game is perfect! The developer wouldn't do something sadistic or downright unfair JUST to make the player upset, right? Nah, you just need to Get Gud, play the game on the hardest difficulty (Because some items don't unlock if you don't play on the hardest difficulty) for almost an entire week FLAWLESSLY.
(We'll just ignore the unspoke achievements as well, like the one where you have to use a specific pill 5 times in one run, of which it has a chance of not appearing, or not picking up any coins or hearts or bombs in one run)
And now, for the final piece to bring it all together! Collecting EVERY single item in the game at least once, all 732 of them! Each with their own chance of spawning, some only in specific rooms, some with less than 1% of a rate to drop! But you would never reset, right? It's not how the game was meant to be played, the game even discourages it by making health run away from you if you do so too much! It takes a while, but you can finally say you 100% the game!
And that's the official 100%!
ONLY the Official 100%!
No need to go looking otherwise at the 2 other save files, which, if you beat THOSE 100% then you'll get a neat little image on your save files for 300% completion!
You TOTALLY spent ONLY a week straight in the game and would call getting the OFFICIAL 100% as enough, right?
You ABSOLUTELY never went upwards of an hour on a run only for you to die in one hit because the game never makes its circular red bullets look different from YOUR circular red bullets, right?
You DEFINITELY DID NOT sink 22 WHOLE DAYS of your life on one save file to a game which asks you to come back every day for 31 days, RIGHT?
Truly, this game is a blast, and is very fun if you plan on doing it casually. But for your own social life if you're a completionist do NOT buy this game. You're better off, trust.

And Edmund I swear to GOD if you add another DLC I will become back my money.

This game really really suffers from Iterative Myopia. It's not objectively a bad game, but its fundamentally a nause to play. The game has had what seems like an obsessively bitter game developer, intentionally punishing his player base in recent years for enjoying his own IP. Filled with unnecessary bloat, annoying RNG and item slop. It can be fun at times, but as others have said the fun is dependant entirely on the luck of your run. Its too unforgiving and in the end annoying to play.

I feel bad for this game, I still like to play it but it need updates so badly.
Over the years of adding contents, which for most is welcome, we can all agree that it made the game infinitely more complex, they doubled the amount of items, more than doubled the amount of trinkets, same for characters and enemies.
And I'm not complaining about that but right now we have borderline beta content, bs rooms, old boss with awful patterns with newer mechanics in the same bundle and I hate that.
Tboi was unfair and rng for the sake of it and right now the game feels like it's entire content is conflicting with each other while before it was about completing 30 marks total now we have 10 times all of what it was, I need to beat this telefrag delirium mess AND beast in the same game, can we update old contents already?

I have the same feelings with the new tainted character, I mostly enjoy all of them (that poop guy is disgusting, i hate it) but items feels not always very well adapted to them, item mechanics are straight up debuff or not working so while they implemented new mechanics to have a fresh new game-play the game still feels like a stats race... because yes, over the years who ever is handling the patches felt like nerfing all Q4 items (mega mush is in the game and solos anything btw) for the sake of it so now, we're no longer able to win with Q4 we also need to pile up damage stats that got a lot more rare to get with all the content they added.

To summarise what I mean, most of the content they added conflict with itself, messes up balance while we could add tons of synergies everywhere with what we already have, we need the old bosses to be updated (delirium, lamb, satan and some elite to name a few) and anything that would avoid me having to stop playing to open up a wiki.

We got item descriptions not long ago, couple enemies has brimstones warning to avoid getting hit across the room and pentagrams where enemies will spawn aswell! All of that are steps in the right direction and is welcome.

Tboi is getting complex and it's fun, I love when I have tons of stuff to do in my games but this one needs to evolve and adapt to it's expensive dlcs, it has SO MUCH to offer... Thanks for reading this far
Great game when I was able to play, but ever since they removed mac support i havent been able to play. GIVE ME MAC COMPATIBILITY!!

I was going to wait until I 100%ed this game to review, as I often do, but I just cannot. This game has been one of my favorites for so long. It is what introduced me to one of my favorite genres of games, all that stuff. That is when I was bad at complex thought. This game is not good. This game seems to be almost entirely luck based, and unlike so many other games in the genre, there is no way to mitigate that fact. There is no way to increase the quantity or quality of items and quite literally nothing is reliable in this game. I can excuse that, to an extent, but what I cannot excuse is the genuine fucking torture that is the tainted characters. The tainted characters are fun a lot of the time, yes. They are also genuinely awful to deal with. Tainted lost is one of the worst gaming experiences I have ever had the displeasure of dealing with. I love risk vs reward characters, and this is a character that expands upon that from one of my favorite characters, base lost. Unlike base lost, however, this one is bullshit. You get one hit per run a lot of the time. Which yes, is the ultimate skill check, but also, in a game that is so built on the leniency of getting hit, considering the bullshit spawning mechanics, tainted lost is so dreadful to play with. There should not be a skill check character in a game that so heavily relies on luck for anything to get done. And on the topic of luck, one of the ONLY ways in which you can mitigate it is by minmaxing every single floor. Which is fine, I enjoy minmaxing because of something that is wrong with me. But of course, there are speedrun achievements, So that is just more luck. And that is compounded when you are playing the other most dreadful character, tainted cain. I like tainted cain in concept. He is just so unfun to play with. Any run with him will take about 3 times as long as a different characters, and you still need speedrun achievements while playing him, which either entails getting the singular crafting recipe that allows you to skip said time requirement, or just not have basically any items. Genuinely fucking dreadful. There are numerous other things I could mention, like a couple of the challenges, which McMillen has gone on record stating that one of them is straight up not fun. but one thing is the fucking price oh my god. If you want the "full" experience, you need to pay for so much dlc. The base game is fine, more enjoyable even, but attempting to move from console to pc or something like that costs so much money. Oh my god and the curses. The fucking curse. On hard mode, which is the main mode you will be using if you want to beat the game, you have a 1 in 3 chance to have a curse on each floor, and they are frankly just not fun. Curses affect information and movement, and only one is even remotely entertaining, the other are just a nuisance, especially curse of the blind. It isn't fun to have less information, all it does is take up more of your time in this timesink of a game. Finally, before i write another essay length review, I just do not like how many achievements there are. I love achievements, but there is an achievement for every single unlock. It feels cheap. I understand the reasoning, but having a game with 644 achievements skews my stats in a way that is simply not that fun. So even outside of the game it causes issues. But for the good, the atmosphere and music is great, as well as the fact that when you do get a good run, it is genuinely very fun (provided you don't get tapped by a random little guy as tainted lost and lose 3 hours of progress without any fault of your own). This is not a very unbiased review. Im just mad. I sure the game is slightly better than I have portrayed it, but none of my critiques have been even close to nitpicks (other than the amount of achievements). Overall, it is a fine game, fun even. Is it a good enough game to actually play? No.
